results.title: Hollywood Costume: Deborah Nadoolman Landis interview
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis, an Oscar nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning catalogue for the exhibition, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes. Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.
In this interview she talks about the origins of the Hollywood Costume industry, working as a costume designer, what a costume designer does and the relationship between the director and the costume designer.

results.title: The Ties that bind
results.creator_credit: Milad Bardan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It took seven years after the death of his mother and a political assassination in his birth country of Lebanon before Milad really got to know his father. This is a tribute to that man.

results.title: Ron Magliozzi and Jenny He interview: 'Tim Burton: The Exhibition'
results.brief_description: Jenny He (Curatorial Assistant, Department of Film) and Ron Magliozzi (Assistant Curator, Department of Film) are co-organizers of the Tim Burton exhibition, from MoMa (The Museum of Modern Art) in New York. Here they are interviewed by Kate Warren, ACMI’s Assistant Curator, about their work on ‘Tim Burton: The Exhibition’. They take us through the process, from inception, through to collaborating with Tim Burton, of Burton’s work and the curatorial process. As well as viewing Tim Burton’s work from an artistic perspective, we also gain insight into the art of the curator and curatorial perspective.

results.title: An Evening with Shaun Tan
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
To celebrate the exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From Book to Film’ a special evening with the Oscar®-winning animator, author and illustrator, Shaun Tan was held on 24 July 2013. He discussed the making of the exhibition, talked about his body of work and shared insights into his creative processes.
Shaun’s books, including ‘The Rabbits’, ‘The Red Tree’ and the acclaimed graphic novel ‘The Arrival’, have been widely translated and enjoyed by readers of all ages. His work as a feature film concept artist can be seen in films like ‘Wall-E’ (2008) and his Academy Award®-winning animated short ‘The Lost Thing’, which he also wrote and co-directed.
In 2011, Shaun received the prestigious Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award in Sweden. His attraction to children’s stories with confronting or puzzling ideas is reflected in his work, which encourages dialogue between adult readers and younger listeners.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: What is Costume Design? with Prof. D. Nadoolman Landis
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In a special event held at ACMI as part of the ‘Hollywood Costume’ exhibition, curator Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis introduced the art of costume design and discussed its role in cinematic storytelling.
Landis, an Oscar®-nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘The Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is also the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning exhibition catalogue, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes.
Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.

results.title: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)
results.brief_description: Melies’ fantastical vision of life on the moon.

constellations_other.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_other.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

results.title_for_label: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)
results.description: One of the first Science Fiction films, this Melies’ short humorously proposes what man discovers when he first lands on the moon. Based on the Jules Verne story, George Melies used his extraordinary cinematic illusions to tell this story of the first voyage to the moon. Made in 1902, this was a visionary film that has come to be recognised as a cinematic masterpiece. Among the many comical set pieces is the famous scene in which a rocket ship crash-lands into the eye of the ‘man in the moon’. This whimsical fantasy is also exemplary in its early depiction of the moon and the possible encounters between humans and worlds beyond our imagining, in our exploration of deep space.
description_for_label: One of the first Science Fiction films, this Melies’ short humorously proposes what man discovers when he first lands on the moon. results.title: Spectacle Talks: Gotye and his Collaborators
results.creator_credit: Gotye, Mike Kenneally, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Multi award-winning musician, songwriter and producer Gotye is no stranger to collaboration. His music videos are a testament to this, utilising the talents of diverse directors, artists and animators. Often involving a range of complex animation and filmmaking techniques, visual worlds are created floating seamlessly against his music.
Natasha Pincus, Andrew Goldsmith, and directors of Rubber House animation studio Ivan Dixon and Greg Sharp disscus a selection of Gotye’s most renowned videos. These include ‘Easy Way Out’, ‘Seven Hours With A Back Seat Driver’, ‘State Of The Art’ and the international chart-topping ‘Somebody That I Used To Know’.
Hosted by film and music critic Megan Spencer, this event provided a fascinating insight into the collaborative journey, from initial concept and creative development, through to final clip production.

results.title: L'Eclipse du Soleil en Pleine Lune
results.brief_description: An aging astronomer invites students to his castle observatory to observe a solar eclipse. Amid the childish pranks of the novice astronomers and the wondrous vision of the eclipse, George Melies, cinema’s great magician, weaves numerous amusing set pieces. Much to the astronomer’s excitement, the sun and the moon flirt with each other as they come together in an astronomical courtship and the sky explodes in a dance of female stars. On earth, the astronomer falls prey to his cheeky students who rob him of his stately dignity, while the heavens smile down on him from above.
